## Description {#details}

Represents either an error or a value T.

ErrorOr&lt;T&gt; is a pointer-like class that represents the result of an operation. The result is either an error, or a value of type T. This is designed to emulate the usage of returning a pointer where nullptr indicates failure. However instead of just knowing that the operation failed, we also have an error&#95;code and optional user data that describes why it failed.

It is used like the following. 
<ProgramListing>

<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal"><a href="#a7efd4fdaf2b3305e13c1358dff404193">ErrorOr&lt;Buffer&gt;</a> getBuffer();</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">auto</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> buffer = getBuffer();</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordflow">if</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> (error&#95;code ec = buffer.getError())</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordflow">return</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> ec;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<CodeLine><Highlight kind="normal">buffer-&gt;write(</Highlight><Highlight kind="stringliteral">&quot;adena&quot;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">);</Highlight></CodeLine>

</ProgramListing>

Implicit conversion to bool returns true if there is a usable value. The unary &#42; and -&gt; operators provide pointer like access to the value. Accessing the value when there is an error has undefined behavior.

When T is a reference type the behavior is slightly different. The reference is held in a std::reference&#95;wrapper&lt;std::remove&#95;reference&lt;T&gt;::type&gt;, and there is special handling to make operator -&gt; work as if T was not a reference.

T cannot be a rvalue reference.

Definition at line 56 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/erroror-h">ErrorOr.h</a>.
